com.hihonor.hiview.description:
This package, like com.hihonor.hiviewtunnel, also doesn't appear to have any use in the Gallery.
There is a similarly named app on Huawei devices which is similarly useless.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.filemanager.description:
Files
Honor's default file manager. You can use another one like MiXplorer.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.contacts.sync.description:
Syncs contacts through Honor's services. There's probably only once or twice you'd ever use this in your life.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.assistant.description:
Honor's YOYO assistant.
I don't use nor trust it with my data so neither should you, probably...
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.koBackup.description:
Backup
It has something to do with Honor's backup service. Pointless since there's already Google backup.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.associateassistant.description:
It could have something to do with YOYO assistant.
Safe to remove if you also removed com.hihonor.assistant.

com.hihonor.hiviewtunnel.description:
On Huawei, this package is in charge of displaying details/attributes of pictures in the gallery (ISO, exposure time, etc.). I don't see any change in the Gallery app when deleting it and com.hihonor.hiview on Honor devices, though. It could just be a useless package existing purely for legacy reasons.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.phoneservice.description:
My HONOR
This app gives you an official store, deals, exclusive services... Basically nothing you'd care about if you wanted to debloat your phone.
Safe to remove..

com.hihonor.android.pushagent.description:
Push notifications for Honor apps. Seems like it's mainly used for analytics.
Notifications from other apps will still appear as normal, thereby safe to remove.

com.hihonor.hnpanpayservice.description: Sounds like the Honor cloud payment service. NFC payment and GPay aren't affected, so it's safe to remove.

com.hihonor.keychain.description:
Password Vault
Honor's password manager.
Safe to remove if you don't use it.

com.hihonor.hncloud.description: Related to Honor cloud services. Probably safe to remove.

com.hihonor.privatespace.description:
PrivateSpace
It's a feature to add a secure hidden system on your device. It's probably Honor's implementation of the Work Profile.
Safe to remove if you don't use this.

com.hihonor.hnmusicplayer.description:
Music Player
Honor's music player app.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.contactscamcard.description:
Scan Business Card
Honor's business card scanner, which scans business cards and adds them to your contacts.
I don't honestly know when you'll ever use it
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.compass.description:
Compass
Honor's compass app.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.numberidentity.description:
Number Identity
Honor's caller identification service.
You can use any other service besides this one, so it's pointless.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.iconnect.description:
It has something to do with Honor Connect.
Pairing of accessories will break if this package doesn't exist, but they will continue to work if they've been paired before removal.
Otherwise safe to remove.

com.hihonor.linktowindowsservice.description:
Something to do with linking your device to Windows.
You shouldn't do this if you don't want to be tracked, and neither should you use Windows (use Arch btw).
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.tips.description:
Tips
Honor Tips app. It gives you tips about how to use your phone.
Since you're here, you probably don't need this.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.lens.description:
HONOR Lens
It's similar to Google Lens. Why don't you use that instead?
This allegedly breaks Magic Text (text recognition from photos), but I'm not sure since my device doesn't support it.
Safe to remove if you don't use any of its features.

com.hihonor.remotepassword.description:
It probably has something to do with recovering forgotten screen locks and Honor ID password with your Honor account.
Removing will most likely break this functionality, everything else should be fine.

com.hihonor.searchservice.description:
Fusion Search Service
Lets you search for things on your device, not unlike Apple's Spotlight Search.
It maybe has something to do with Circle to Search on your device, but I can't tell.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.contacts.description:
Contacts
Honor's contacts app.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.videoeditor.description:
Cut
Honor's built in video editor. You can access this through the gallery app.
Safe to remove if you don't use this.

com.hihonor.synergy.description:
Honor Cloud & Network Synergy.
Seems to be related to B2B (Business to Business) cloud stuff.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.calendar.description:
Calendar
Honor's calendar app.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.gameassistant.description:
Game Manager
Overlay which has tools for 'boosting' your device performance when playing games. It sometimes mistakes apps like ibisPaint for being a game, which is annoying.
I don't quite trust that it would actually make your performance that much better, but it should be up to you whether or not to remove it.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.livewallpaper.paradise.description:
Honor's live wallpaper app.
Safe to remove if you don't use their live wallpapers.

com.hihonor.hisight.description:
Appears to be related to Honor HiVision, which gives you AR stuff and an AI camera.
Safe to remove if you also removed com.hihonor.hiview.

com.hihonor.hnoffice.description: The document processing backend of Honor Docs. Safe to remove if you also removed com.hihonor.fileservice..

com.hihonor.bluetooth.description:
It's used by Honor Contacts to import contacts via Bluetooth. Sounds trashy and probably nobody would ever use it.
It doesn't have anything to do with the system's Bluetooth implementation.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.parallelspace.description:
Parallel Space
It's like Samsung's Secure Folder, from what I've read.
Safe to remove if you don't use this.

com.hihonor.autoinstallapkfrommmc.description:
Not sure what its purpose is, but from the package name it appears to install apps based on your Mobile Country Code, i.e. region based apps.
Most likely only ever used during setup, therefore pointless after that.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.magazine.description:
Provides a daily feed on the stock Honor Home launcher. It probably tracks you a lot.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.crossdeviceserviceshare.description: I suspect that it's part of Honor Connect for you to share data across devices connected through it. Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.game.kitserver.description:
Related to game boosting.
Safe to remove if you also removed com.hihonor.gameassistant.

com.hihonor.appmarket.description:
App Market
Honor's app store. Why would you use this...
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.browserhomepage.description:
Probably a custom homepage for Chrome. Pointless.
Safe to remove!

com.hihonor.pcassistant.description:
It's used to connect to your PC via HiSuite. Unrelated to ADB connections.
Safe to remove if you don't use HiSuite.

com.hihonor.search.description:
This is the search function when you swipe up in the default Honor Home launcher. I don't like it.
Safe to remove if you don't use this.

com.hihonor.airlink.description:
Something related to Honor Connect.
This package only manages the pairing of Honor accessories. They will continue to work without it if they've already been paired.
Safe to remove if you dont own and are not planning on owning any Honor accessories...

com.hihonor.controlcenter.description:
It's the MagicRing section in the control center.
MagicRing lets you connect other Honor devices so you can have screen mirroring, app continuity, file transfers, and other pointless stuff. I hate ecosystems like this, I really do.
Safe to remove if you don't use this.

com.hihonor.aipluginengine.description:
Related to Honor AI. It could break some 'smart' capabilities across system apps. I hate AI.
Safe to remove if you don't use it.

com.hihonor.mcs.media.avfoundation.description:
Not exactly sure what it is, but judging from the title, it should have something to do with AVFoundation, a multimedia framework made by Apple.
I didn't see any issues with media in system apps. Safe to remove if you don't care about it.

com.hihonor.mediamaterial.description: I've not much clue as to what this does. Nobody's seen any side effect from removing.

com.hihonor.photos.description:
Gallery
Honor's gallery app. Removing it will disallow you to open the most recently taken photo in the camera app. It also bars you from changing the wallpaper from the Settings app, but using different apps to change the wallpaper still works.
Safe to remove if you can bear these consequences.

com.hihonor.hnmediagraph.description:
I've not a good idea what this does, but the Cut app (com.hihonor.videoeditor) has permissions to read from and write to it.
Nobody's seen any side effect from removing.

com.hihonor.systemappsupdater.description:
This package is in charge of updating system apps. Doesn't affect anything else and also probably won't affect system apps updating via OTA updates.
Safe to remove if you don't want it.

com.hihonor.android.instantshare.description:
HONOR Share
It lets you transfer files to other Honor devices in the sharesheet. Also part of their stupid ecosystem. It doesn't affect Android's sharesheet functionality.
Nobody uses this. You should remove it.

com.hihonor.cooperatedconfig.description:
Collaborative configuration probably has something to do with Honor Connect and MagicRing.
Safe to remove if you don't use them.

com.hihonor.android.chr.description:
There's a similarly named app on Huawei devices which has something to do with Call History Records.
Safe to remove if you don't use the stock Honor phone app.

com.hihonor.FloatTasks.description:
The Navigation Dock feature you can enable under System navigation.
Safe to remove if you don't use it.

com.hihonor.brain.description:
Probably something to do with Honor AI or some Magic Live service.
Safe to remove if you don't use them.

com.hihonor.devicegroupmanage.description:
It could be related to Honor Connect and maybe has something to do with managing groups.
Probably safe to remove if you don't use these.

com.hihonor.awareness.description:
This is related to Honor AI and YOYO assistant.
A user on XDA Forums reported that the Honor Magic Pen won't pair if this package doesn't exist. This is not the case with the Honor Choice Pencil, but I don't own any other styluses from Honor so I can't say anything about them.
Safe to remove if you don't use any of these features.

com.hihonor.hnstartupguide.description:
This is the app you see when you first set up your phone. Pretty useless after that.
Safe to remove if you've already set up your device.

com.hihonor.handoff.description:
It provides some functionality of Honor Connect.
Safe to remove if you don't use it.

com.hihonor.detectrepair.description:
Intelligent Diagnosis
It's a feature which lets you diagnose your phone for issues. It is only accessible via the My Honor app, but runs in the background.
Safe to remove if you don't use it.

com.hihonor.medialibrary.description:
This is needed for the camera app.
On some devices, if removed or disabled, camera will crash after taking a photo.

com.hihonor.android.internal.app.description: This is needed for the Android Sharesheet. Removing this will cause some apps to crash when trying to bring up the Sharesheet.

com.hihonor.android.launcher.description:
Honor Home is the default launcher.
Removing this package on Honor devices will break system navigation, and multitasking will just not work.
You can replace it with another launcher, but this app is still responsible for navigations.

com.hihonor.systemmanager.description: Removing or disabling this app will cause you to not be able to set app permissions.

com.hihonor.stylus.floatmenu.description:
This is the floating stylus menu. Upon removal, stylus settings in Accessibility features -> Stylus disappear, making configuration and updates impossible.
Safe to remove if you don't use a stylus.

com.hihonor.featurelayer.sharedfeature.s.description: I assume this package manages stylus-specific functions, like pressure sensitivity and whatnot, but removing it doesn't affect my Honor Choice Pencil's functionality. But I guess having 'stylus' in the name should be enough for you to not remove it if you use a stylus, right?

com.hihonor.powergenie.description:
A similarly named app on Huawei devices specifically exists to kill processes running in the background to 'save battery', even if they have wakelock. This is detrimental for tasks which require you to have a process always running in the background, on Termux for example.
The hypocrites at Huawei/Honor whitelist some system apps and others like Facebook and Baidu from being able to be killed by PowerGenie.
Some users on the r/Huawei Reddit state that after removing PowerGenie their device starts to become unstable.
On Huawei devices, removing this app will usually cause your device to instantly reboot with the app reinstalled. Honor won't do that, but it will be reinstalled on a reboot.
More info: https://dontkillmyapp.com/huawei

com.hihonor.iaware.description:
A similarly named app on Huawei devices allegedly manages the auto starting of apps, and 'prioritises them to avoid slowdown'. Probably don't remove this package.
https://xdaforums.com/t/guide-list-of-bloatware-on-emui-safe-to-remove.3700814/page-6

com.hihonor.magicvoice.description: Not sure what it does exactly, but clearly it has something to do with AI. It could possibly be the AI Voice detection features on newer phones, or something to do with the YOYO assistant. Either way, safe to remove if you don't use AI features.

androidhnext.description: It's probably part of the MagicOS framework. /system/framework/framework-res-hnext.apk. Removing this messes with accessing files outside of /sdcard for some reason, but it recovers somehow. I therefore have reason to believe that this package is unsafe to remove.

com.hihonor.audioaccessorymanager.description:
As the name suggests, this package manages Huawei/Honor branded audio accessories and eyewear.
For some reason, this package can store an arbritrary amount of data ranging from 100mb to 2gb worth of data in some cases.
Probably safe to disable if you don't use any compatible accessories, but removing it could be another thing entirely.

com.hihonor.camera.description:
Camera
Honor's camera app. Remove if you don't want to take pictures, I guess.
Has no side effects after removal from my observations.

com.hihonor.cameraextension.description: I assume this provides the camera service to the Honor camera app and other apps which want it, but removing it doesnt seem to do anything to the functionality. I may be wrong, or it might not be the entire truth, so exercise caution when removing.

com.hihonor.frameworkreshnext.overlay.description: MagicOS framework overlay. I won't even try to remove this.

com.hihonor.credentialmanager.overlay.description: I think it has something to do with Credential Manager (com.android.credentialmanager) on Honor devices.

com.hihonor.hnbluetoothpencilmanager.description:
It manages Honor styluses.
They will pair without this package, but the stylus will not work, you will lose stylus battery info, and stylus settings will disappear.
The stylus works like normal when the package is removed after pairing, but you will still lose battery info and settings.
Safe to remove if you don't use a stylus and are not planning on having one.

com.hihonor.permissioncontroller.overlay.description: I think it has something to do with Permission Controller (com.google.permissioncontroller) on Honor devices.

com.hihonor.safetycenter.resources.overl.description:
Honor theme overlay for com.google.android.safetycenter.resources.
Never had any problem with the Security and Privacy settings after removing this.

com.hihonor.safetycenter.styles.overlay.description:
Honor styles overlay for com.google.android.safetycenter.resources.
Never had any problem with the Security and Privacy settings after removing this.

com.hihonor.ddmp.description: My research has found not much about this. All I can tell about it is that it manages your data, or something... It appears to not be running except during boot.

com.hihonor.printservice.description:
Default Print Service
Honor's print service.
Safe to remove if you don't print/want to use a different print service.

com.hihonor.trustcircle.description:
There is a similarly named app on Huawei devices.
It's unknown what it does, but it most likely has something to do with authenticating your device with an Honor account.
Probably safe to remove if you don't have an account.

com.hihonor.collectcenter.description:
Favourites Space
It's a feature on Honor phones which lets you quickly save text, and files.
Safe to remove if you don't use this.

com.hihonor.globalwrite.description:
Global Handwriting
Handwriting plugin for styluses on Honor phones.
Safe to remove if you don't use a stylus.

com.hihonor.fileservice.description:
Honor Docs
This is Honor's document processing app. It's nothing special and you can use a different one.
Safe to remove.

com.hihonor.systemserver.description:
A similarly named app exists on Huawei devices. From uad_lists.json:
Do not remove this. You lose phone functionality.

com.hihonor.lbs.description:
A similarly named app exists on Huawei devices. From uad_lists.json:
Location service? After removing it location still works, so no one knows what this app does
Location will still work on Honor devices after it's removed, therefore it's safe to do so.

com.hihonor.id.description:
Magic Mobile Service
It lets you manage your Honor ID account.
Safe to remove if you don't have one.

com.hihonor.mediadatacenter.description: I've completely got no clue what it does. Doesn't seem to have any effect after removing, though.

com.hihonor.mediaprocessor.description: Processes media... Probably. Doesn't seem to have any effect on media related tasks on system apps, though.

com.hihonor.motionservice.description: Not very useful gestures available in Settings.

com.hihonor.hndockbar.description:
Honor's multi-window dock on the side of the screen.
Safe to remove if you don't use it.

com.hihonor.msdp.description:
A similarly named app exists on Huawei devices. From uad_lists.json:
Has Device Status, Movement, Spatial Aware.

com.hihonor.carrierlocation.description: Could send location data to your ISP, or maybe the other way around.

com.hihonor.desktop.explorer.description:
This is the service used to mirror your device's screen to displays wirelessly.
Safe to remove if you also removed com.hihonor.android.mirrorshare.

com.hihonor.projectmenu.description:
A similarly named app exists on Huawei devices.
It's hidden settings not available to users. ProjectMenu interface: phone *#*#2846579#*#*

com.hihonor.coauthservice.description:
A similarly named app exists on Huawei devices. From uad_lists.json:
Applock, lockscreen password, face recognition things, fingerprint, not sure if it's worth removing it. Needed for manual apk installation.

com.hihonor.securityserver.description: A similarly named app exists on Huawei devices. Needed for face unlock, otherwise a black screen will be shown. Doesn't apply to all devices.

com.hihonor.sws.description: 3D audio effects and other stuff. Causes minor audio glitches but otherwise safe.

com.hihonor.thememanager.description: Honor Theme Manager. Safe to remove if you don't use this.

com.hihonor.deviceauth.description: I guess it's for authentication keys.

com.hihonor.visionengine.description:
I assume it has something to do with Honor AI Lens, or some other stuff.
Safe to remove if you don't use any AI features.

com.hihonor.wallpapereditor.description:
It allows you to set your wallpaper through the Settings app.
You still can set wallpapers from other apps.

com.hihonor.mirrorshare.description:
Wireless Projection
It lets you mirror your device's screen to displays wirelessly. Note that it won't work without com.hihonor.desktop explorer.
Safe to remove if you don't use it.
